</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp010" view="all">► Simple acid–base reaction is very efficient for large-scale synthesis of zinc MAFs. ► MAFs from the reaction have higher chemical stability compared with other methods. ► MAFs show unique pore size/surface characteristic and framework flexibility. ► MAF-4 and MAF-5 are suitable for removal of trace aromatic molecules from water.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

      

Highlights

► Simple acid-base reaction is very efficient for large-scale synthesis of zinc MAFs. ► MAFs from the reaction have higher chemical stability compared with other methods. ► MAFs show unique pore size/surface characteristic and framework flexibility. ► MAF-4 and MAF-5 are suitable for removal of trace aromatic molecules from water.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0035">

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Acid-base neutralization reaction between monoalkyl-substituted azole derivatives and ZnO/Zn(OH)2 can be effectively activated by aqueous ammonia to synthesize a series of metal azolate frameworks (MAFs) including SOD-[Zn(mim)2] (MAF-4, Hmim=2-methylimidazole), ANA-[Zn(eim)2] (MAF-5, Heim=2-ethylimidazole), SOD-[Zn(mtz)2] (MAF-7, Hmtz=3-methyl-1,2,4-triazole), dia-[Zn(mim)2] (MAF-31), qtz-[Zn(eim)2] (MAF-32), and dia-[Zn(etz)2] (MAF-33, Hetz=3-ethyl-1,2,4-triazole). The porous zeolitic MAFs obtained by this reaction possess high stability and can be easily activated. Their high porosity, unique pore size/surface characteristic, and framework flexibility were demonstrated by gas and solvent vapor (water, methanol, and benzene) sorption measurements. The imidazolate frameworks MAF-4 and MAF-5 are highly hydrophobic adsorbents with exceptional organic/water selectivity, while the triazolate framework MAF-7 containing uncoordinated nitrogen donor on the pore surface exhibits higher sorption affinity and lower stability. Despite the very small aperture sizes (3.2-3.4Å), the SOD frameworks can readily adsorb large organic molecules by temporary distortion of the structure.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are of great current interest for potential applications, but their rational construction remains a great challenge . Recently, metal azolate frameworks (MAFs) composed of deprotonated polyazaheterocycles, such as pyrazolates, imidazolates, and triazolates, have received considerable attention, because the strong coordination ability and simple coordination behavior of azolate ligands are beneficial for structure prediction and framework stability . Among several types of MAFs studied, zeolitic frameworks constructed by imidazolate derivatives are of particular interest . Although many tetrahedral metal ions are available, they tend to from diamond topology (dia) with common (linear) ditopic linkers, and zeolitic topologies are relatively rare despite their importance and rich occurrence in inorganic materials . Compared with the highly symmetric dia topology, a bended (no strict requirement for the bending angle) linker breaks the perfect tetrahedral T d symmetry around the metal center and introduces structural diversity with multiple energy minima. The bended exo-bidentate bridging mode of imidazolate is similar to the oxygen atom in zeolites ( ), meaning that tetrahedral metal imidazolate frameworks are potential zeolite mimics. The structural similarity between metal imidazolate and aluminosilicate was first illustrated by You and co-workers with a variety of zeolite-like, isomeric cobalt imidazolate frameworks [Co(im)2] synthesized by the aid of solvothermal reaction, template and/or structural directing agent .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">As seen in other MAF systems, the substituent groups of the azolate ligands play important roles in controlling the precise topology, while the basic topological features such as connectivity are determined by the metal ions (charge and available coordination geometry) and the type of azolate . Using a liquid diffusion approach, we synthesized SOD-[Zn(bim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-3, Hbim<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>benzimidazole) as the first porous metal imidazolate with framework topology mathematically identical to zeolite . While the porosity is limited by the presence of bulky side group and framework distortion, MAF-3 has been widely studied for separation applications . We further used 2-alkylimidazolates and employed a mixed-ligand strategy to discover three new metal imidazolates, i.e. SOD-[Zn(mim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-4, Hmim<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2-methylimidazole), ANA-[Zn(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-5, Heim<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2-ethylimidazole), and RHO-[Zn(mim/eim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-6), with not only regular zeolitic structures but also very high thermal stability and porosity . Recently, we synthesized the first triazolate-based zeolitic framework SOD-[Zn(mtz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-7, Hmtz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3-methyl-1,2,4-triazole), which showed less thermal stability but possesses much higher adsorption affinity than for the imidazolate analog MAF-4, due to the presence of uncoordinated nitrogen donors on the pore surface .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As seen in other MAF systems, the substituent groups of the azolate ligands play important roles in controlling the precise topology, while the basic topological features such as connectivity are determined by the metal ions (charge and available coordination geometry) and the type of azolate . Using a liquid diffusion approach, we synthesized SOD-[Zn(bim)2] (MAF-3, Hbim=benzimidazole) as the first porous metal imidazolate with framework topology mathematically identical to zeolite . While the porosity is limited by the presence of bulky side group and framework distortion, MAF-3 has been widely studied for separation applications . We further used 2-alkylimidazolates and employed a mixed-ligand strategy to discover three new metal imidazolates, i.e. SOD-[Zn(mim)2] (MAF-4, Hmim=2-methylimidazole), ANA-[Zn(eim)2] (MAF-5, Heim=2-ethylimidazole), and RHO-[Zn(mim/eim)2] (MAF-6), with not only regular zeolitic structures but also very high thermal stability and porosity . Recently, we synthesized the first triazolate-based zeolitic framework SOD-[Zn(mtz)2] (MAF-7, Hmtz=3-methyl-1,2,4-triazole), which showed less thermal stability but possesses much higher adsorption affinity than for the imidazolate analog MAF-4, due to the presence of uncoordinated nitrogen donors on the pore surface .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Continuous efforts have been devoted to exploring new structures and interesting properties for this special kind of PCPs . For example, Yaghi and co-workers successfully introduced the high-throughout solvothermal method to enumerate a number of intriguing new zeolitic structures . They also showed that MAF-4 possess exceptional chemical stability in boiling organic solvent, water, and even aqueous NaOH , which is very noteworthy compared with other types of PCPs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Continuous efforts have been devoted to exploring new structures and interesting properties for this special kind of PCPs . For example, Yaghi and co-workers successfully introduced the high-throughout solvothermal method to enumerate a number of intriguing new zeolitic structures . They also showed that MAF-4 possess exceptional chemical stability in boiling organic solvent, water, and even aqueous NaOH , which is very noteworthy compared with other types of PCPs.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Facile, efficient, economic, environment-friendly, and large-scale synthetic methods are essential for industrial production and applications of PCPs . For example, many synthetic studies have been carried out for MAF-4 , but the known synthetic methods have disadvantages in yield, byproduct, activation, product-quality, efficiency, and/or economy, etc. To overcome the solubility problem and obtain high-quality single crystals, liquid diffusion and solvothermal procedures have been widely applied for synthesizing MAFs. However, liquid diffusion usually needs long reaction times and can be hardly scaled up . Solvothermal reactions require high boiling-point organic solvents such as amides as the templates or structure-directing agents, which are difficult to be recycled and removed from the cavities of MAFs . Meanwhile, the use of soluble metal salts in common synthetic reactions always results in large quantity of intractable byproducts.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Facile, efficient, economic, environment-friendly, and large-scale synthetic methods are essential for industrial production and applications of PCPs . For example, many synthetic studies have been carried out for MAF-4 , but the known synthetic methods have disadvantages in yield, byproduct, activation, product-quality, efficiency, and/or economy, etc. To overcome the solubility problem and obtain high-quality single crystals, liquid diffusion and solvothermal procedures have been widely applied for synthesizing MAFs. However, liquid diffusion usually needs long reaction times and can be hardly scaled up . Solvothermal reactions require high boiling-point organic solvents such as amides as the templates or structure-directing agents, which are difficult to be recycled and removed from the cavities of MAFs . Meanwhile, the use of soluble metal salts in common synthetic reactions always results in large quantity of intractable byproducts.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Considering the unique characteristics of MAFs, they might be synthesized by the simple acid–base neutralization reaction, which requires the cheap metal source oxide or hydroxide as starting material, and produces no waste but water. Appropriate activation method is needed to accelerate the heterogeneous reaction involving the weak acids (azoles). Recently, several zeolitic MAFs have been synthesized by mechanochemical reaction with solvent and/or ammonium salt as additives . We also showed that several zeolitic/porous MAFs can be synthesized very efficiently by simply heating the mixture of metal oxide/hydroxide and azole ligand without addition of any solvent or additive . MAF-4 sample synthesized by this solvent/additive-free method can be directly used for adsorptive applications, with porosity only slightly lower than the highest reported values. Aqueous ammonia may be used as another activation method, which has been successfully applied for Ag(I) and Cu(I) based MAFs . For Zn(II) based zeolitic MAFs, aqueous ammonia has been used in the liquid diffusion and rapid solution mixing reactions with Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and soluble Zn(II) salts as starting materials, respectively, which still suffered from problems of low efficiency, byproduct, and/or recyclability .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Considering the unique characteristics of MAFs, they might be synthesized by the simple acid-base neutralization reaction, which requires the cheap metal source oxide or hydroxide as starting material, and produces no waste but water. Appropriate activation method is needed to accelerate the heterogeneous reaction involving the weak acids (azoles). Recently, several zeolitic MAFs have been synthesized by mechanochemical reaction with solvent and/or ammonium salt as additives . We also showed that several zeolitic/porous MAFs can be synthesized very efficiently by simply heating the mixture of metal oxide/hydroxide and azole ligand without addition of any solvent or additive . MAF-4 sample synthesized by this solvent/additive-free method can be directly used for adsorptive applications, with porosity only slightly lower than the highest reported values. Aqueous ammonia may be used as another activation method, which has been successfully applied for Ag(I) and Cu(I) based MAFs . For Zn(II) based zeolitic MAFs, aqueous ammonia has been used in the liquid diffusion and rapid solution mixing reactions with Zn(OH)2 and soluble Zn(II) salts as starting materials, respectively, which still suffered from problems of low efficiency, byproduct, and/or recyclability .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Herein, we report a comprehensive synthetic study for a series of zeolitic MAFs using the simple acid–base neutralization reaction using ZnO/Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> as the starting material. Four monoalkyl substituted imidazoles and 1,2,4-triazoles were used as ligands. Aqueous ammonia was used as a recyclable and effective activation agent. Liquid diffusion, rapid solution mixing, heterogeneous mixing, slow evaporation, solvothermal and microwave treatments were considered for the syntheses of single-crystal and micro-crystalline MAFs. Thermal and chemical stabilities and sorption properties of the obtained MAFs have been studied in detail.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report a comprehensive synthetic study for a series of zeolitic MAFs using the simple acid-base neutralization reaction using ZnO/Zn(OH)2 as the starting material. Four monoalkyl substituted imidazoles and 1,2,4-triazoles were used as ligands. Aqueous ammonia was used as a recyclable and effective activation agent. Liquid diffusion, rapid solution mixing, heterogeneous mixing, slow evaporation, solvothermal and microwave treatments were considered for the syntheses of single-crystal and micro-crystalline MAFs. Thermal and chemical stabilities and sorption properties of the obtained MAFs have been studied in detail.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">3-Methyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hmtz) and 3-ethyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hetz) were synthesized according to the literature method . ZnO, Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, concentrated aqueous ammonia (25%, denoted as CAA hereafter), methanol, and other reagents were commercially available and used without further purification.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials

3-Methyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hmtz) and 3-ethyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hetz) were synthesized according to the literature method . ZnO, Zn(OH)2, concentrated aqueous ammonia (25%, denoted as CAA hereafter), methanol, and other reagents were commercially available and used without further purification.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Physical measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Infrared (IR) spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Bruker TENSOR 27 Fourier Transform Infrared spectrometer in the 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed at a rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> using a NETZSCH TG 209 system. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Rigaku D/M-2200T automated diffractometer or a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα). Gas and water vapor sorption isotherms were measured on a volumetric adsorption apparatus (BELSORP-max, Bel, Japan). Organic solvent vapor sorption isotherms were measured on an automatic gravimetric adsorption apparatus (IGA-003 series, Hiden Isochema Ltd.). Before each sorption experiment, the sample was heated at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under high vacuum for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Physical measurements

Infrared (IR) spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Bruker TENSOR 27 Fourier Transform Infrared spectrometer in the 400-4000cm-1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed at a rate of 10°C/min under N2 using a NETZSCH TG 209 system. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Rigaku D/M-2200T automated diffractometer or a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα). Gas and water vapor sorption isotherms were measured on a volumetric adsorption apparatus (BELSORP-max, Bel, Japan). Organic solvent vapor sorption isotherms were measured on an automatic gravimetric adsorption apparatus (IGA-003 series, Hiden Isochema Ltd.). Before each sorption experiment, the sample was heated at 120°C under high vacuum for 2h.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

All MAF samples were synthesized in the acid-base neutralization reaction mechanism started with the corresponding azole ligand (2mmol) and ZnO or Zn(OH)2 (1mmol). Several methods are employed to accomplish the reactions:  (1) Rapid solution mixing: ZnO/Zn(OH)2 was dissolved in a minimum amount of CAA, to which a solution of an azole ligand is added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 5h, and then filtered, washed by methanol, and dried at 120°C in air to give white powder as the product.   (2) Heterogeneous mixing: ZnO/Zn(OH)2, an azole ligand, and a ‘reaction solvent' were mixed and stirred at room temperature or (microwave) heated in a sealed vessel. Workup procedure followed method 1. The ‘reaction solvent' can be pure water, methanol, CAA, mixture of these reagents, or mother liquor obtained from method 1 and 2.   (3) Slow solution mixing (liquid diffusion): A methanol solution of an azole ligand (0.050mol/L) was carefully layered on the CAA solution of ZnO/Zn(OH)2 (0.025mol/L). Single crystals were obtained after several days.   (4) Slow evaporation: ZnO/Zn(OH)2 and an azole ligand were added with an excess amount of CAA, and then the mixture was filtered to get a clear solution, which was allowed to evaporate slowly. Single crystals were obtained after several days.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Typical synthetic procedures for the studied MAFs</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">SOD-[Zn(mim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-4): Single crystals were obtained by method 3 . Powder samples were obtained by method 1 (yield: 75%) or 2 (yield:>95%). In method 1, a methanol solution of Hmim (0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L) was used. In method 2, when the ‘reaction solution’ is methanol added with CAA (20%, v/v), the reaction time is 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h for room temperature stirring, or 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h for 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C solvothermal treatment, or 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h for 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C microwave-assisted solvotherml treatment; when the ‘reaction solution’ is methanol added with water (20%, v/v), the reaction time is 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h for 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C solvothermal treatment, or 2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h for 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C microwave-assisted solvothermal treatment.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Typical synthetic procedures for the studied MAFs

SOD-[Zn(mim)2] (MAF-4): Single crystals were obtained by method 3 . Powder samples were obtained by method 1 (yield: 75%) or 2 (yield:>95%). In method 1, a methanol solution of Hmim (0.1mol/L) was used. In method 2, when the ‘reaction solution' is methanol added with CAA (20%, v/v), the reaction time is 24h for room temperature stirring, or 24h for 40°C solvothermal treatment, or 1.5h for 40°C microwave-assisted solvotherml treatment; when the ‘reaction solution' is methanol added with water (20%, v/v), the reaction time is 24h for 180°C solvothermal treatment, or 2.5h for 120°C microwave-assisted solvothermal treatment.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">ANA-[Zn(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-5): Single crystals  and powder samples were obtained in similar ways as MAF-4. A small amount of benzene (5%, v/v) was added into the ligand solution for method 1 (yield: 80%), or into the ‘reaction solvent’ for method 2 (yield: >95%).</ce:para>

dia-[Zn(mim)2] (MAF-31): Single crystals were obtained by method 4 (yield: 70%).

 qtz-[Zn(eim)2] (MAF-32): Single crystals were obtained by method 4 (yield: 93%).

 dia-[Zn(etz)2] (MAF-33): Single crystals were obtained by method 4 (yield: 63%).

X-ray crystallography

Diffraction intensities were collected on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation, equipped with an open dry nitrogen flow temperature controller. Absorption corrections were applied by using multi-scan program SADABS . The structures were solved with direct methods and refined with a full-matrix least-squares technique with the SHELXTL program package . Anisotropic thermal parameters were applied to all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically and refined in a riding mode ( ).

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Using monoalkyl substituted azoles 2-methylimidazole (Hmim), 2-ethylimidazole (Heim), 3-methyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hmtz), and 3-ethyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hetz) as starting materials, six binary MAFs, namely SOD-[Zn(mim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-4), ANA-[Zn(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-5), SOD-[Zn(mtz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-7), <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold>-[Zn(mim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-31), <ce:bold>qtz</ce:bold>-[Zn(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-32), and <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold>-[Zn(etz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-33) were obtained. Single-crystal structures of as-synthesized MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7 were first described in our previous communications . The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O sorption behaviors of isostructural MAF-4 and MAF-7 were also discussed, but the sorption property of MAF-5 has not been observed. Crystal structures of MAF-31  and MAF-32  were reported by other groups very recently, while MAF-33 has not been reported. To better understand the relationship among synthesis, structure, and property, single-crystal structures of guest-free MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7 were measured and compared with the nonporous compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Using monoalkyl substituted azoles 2-methylimidazole (Hmim), 2-ethylimidazole (Heim), 3-methyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hmtz), and 3-ethyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hetz) as starting materials, six binary MAFs, namely SOD-[Zn(mim)2] (MAF-4), ANA-[Zn(eim)2] (MAF-5), SOD-[Zn(mtz)2] (MAF-7), dia-[Zn(mim)2] (MAF-31), qtz-[Zn(eim)2] (MAF-32), and dia-[Zn(etz)2] (MAF-33) were obtained. Single-crystal structures of as-synthesized MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7 were first described in our previous communications . The N2, H2, CO2, C2H2, and H2O sorption behaviors of isostructural MAF-4 and MAF-7 were also discussed, but the sorption property of MAF-5 has not been observed. Crystal structures of MAF-31  and MAF-32  were reported by other groups very recently, while MAF-33 has not been reported. To better understand the relationship among synthesis, structure, and property, single-crystal structures of guest-free MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7 were measured and compared with the nonporous compounds.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Framework structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The guest-free structures are iso-structural to the as-synthesized phases, demonstrating the robustness of the porous frameworks. MAF-4 crystallizes in the cubic space group <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>-43<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>, the highest possible for SOD zeolites. Symmetry lowering from the highest symmetry <ce:italic>Im</ce:italic>-3<ce:italic>m</ce:italic> for SOD topology is gathered from the incorporation of bended linker . Although <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">d</ce:inf> symmetry of tetrahedral center is canceled by the bended ligands, the zinc atoms in MAF-4, locating at −4 positions, are still in virtually regular tetrahedral coordination environment (Zn–N 1.983(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, N–Zn–N 109.46(19)–109.47(10)°). Note that the 4-connected nodes in an idealized SOD topology are significantly distorted (T–T–T<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90° or 120°) from <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">d</ce:inf> symmetry. Similar to inorganic zeolites, the incompatibility between regular tetrahedral building block and zeolitic topology is fixed by the bended linker. The good matching of SOD topology and the molecular building blocks can be also judged from the perfect co-planarity between the metal ion and the aromatic ring (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Further, the orientation of mim<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand is noteworthy, which may minimize steric hindrance and maximize dipole–dipole interactions by pointing the methyl group to the center of the ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> triangular face (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>a). Each methyl group fixes two adjacent ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> tetrahedra in the same way and accomplishes an eclipsed conformation with a mirror plane passing through the C–C single bond of mim<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (b), which is a key structural feature of the SOD topology. Obviously, the suitable size and/or polarity of methyl group are crucial for such a structure directing effect. Other substituent groups may behave in similar ways but lead to other superstructures owing to the different size and shape.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Framework structures

The guest-free structures are iso-structural to the as-synthesized phases, demonstrating the robustness of the porous frameworks. MAF-4 crystallizes in the cubic space group I-43m, the highest possible for SOD zeolites. Symmetry lowering from the highest symmetry Im-3m for SOD topology is gathered from the incorporation of bended linker . Although T d symmetry of tetrahedral center is canceled by the bended ligands, the zinc atoms in MAF-4, locating at -4 positions, are still in virtually regular tetrahedral coordination environment (Zn-N 1.983(3)Å, N-Zn-N 109.46(19)-109.47(10)°). Note that the 4-connected nodes in an idealized SOD topology are significantly distorted (T-T-T=90° or 120°) from T d symmetry. Similar to inorganic zeolites, the incompatibility between regular tetrahedral building block and zeolitic topology is fixed by the bended linker. The good matching of SOD topology and the molecular building blocks can be also judged from the perfect co-planarity between the metal ion and the aromatic ring ( ). Further, the orientation of mim- ligand is noteworthy, which may minimize steric hindrance and maximize dipole-dipole interactions by pointing the methyl group to the center of the ZnN3 triangular face ( a). Each methyl group fixes two adjacent ZnN4 tetrahedra in the same way and accomplishes an eclipsed conformation with a mirror plane passing through the C-C single bond of mim- (b), which is a key structural feature of the SOD topology. Obviously, the suitable size and/or polarity of methyl group are crucial for such a structure directing effect. Other substituent groups may behave in similar ways but lead to other superstructures owing to the different size and shape.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">The SOD network can be described as truncated octahedral (4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">8</ce:sup>) cages fused on the 4- and 6-rings. Since the 4-ring openings are too small, the large cavities (<ce:italic>d<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>11.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) in MAF-4 are only accessible to each other by the eight 6-rings (<ce:italic>d<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), which defines a 3D intersecting pore system (void<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>49.8%) with a <ce:bold>bcu</ce:bold> topology (c) . The complete coordination of all nitrogen donors eliminates any coordination or hydrophilic site on the pore surface, and incorporation of hydrophobic methyl groups further increases the surface hydrophobicity. Despite that tetrahedral zinc ions are regarded as co-ordinatively unsaturated, each ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> triangular face is protected by a methyl group (a), ensuring a hydrophobic pore surface. It should be noted that, hydrophobic adsorbents, especially those with large cavities connected through very small apertures are extremely scarce, though this kind of porous material may be used for advanced separation applications.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The SOD network can be described as truncated octahedral (4668) cages fused on the 4- and 6-rings. Since the 4-ring openings are too small, the large cavities (d =11.4Å) in MAF-4 are only accessible to each other by the eight 6-rings (d =3.2Å), which defines a 3D intersecting pore system (void=49.8%) with a bcu topology (c) . The complete coordination of all nitrogen donors eliminates any coordination or hydrophilic site on the pore surface, and incorporation of hydrophobic methyl groups further increases the surface hydrophobicity. Despite that tetrahedral zinc ions are regarded as co-ordinatively unsaturated, each ZnN3 triangular face is protected by a methyl group (a), ensuring a hydrophobic pore surface. It should be noted that, hydrophobic adsorbents, especially those with large cavities connected through very small apertures are extremely scarce, though this kind of porous material may be used for advanced separation applications.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0100" view="all">MAF-7 is isomorphous with MAF-4. Their slightly different unit-cell parameters reflect size difference between the triazolate and imidazolate rings, or the nitrogen and carbon atoms. The ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> geometry in MAF-7 (Zn–N 1.980(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, N–Zn–N 108.62(15)–109.90(8)°) is slightly deviated from a regular tetrahedron. Although triazolates often behave as μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-linkers in coordination compounds and Zn(II) can also adopt an octahedral coordination geometry, mtz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> in MAF-7 uses only the 2- and 4-nitrogens for coordination, leaving the 1-nitrogen unbound. The waste of one coordination site should be ascribed to the steric hindrance of the hypothetical (3,6)-connected structure. Because mtz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> does not contain a mirror symmetry along its C–C single bond, the 1-nitrogen in MAF-7 is symmetrically disordered with the 5-carbon (). The pore parameters of MAF-7 (cavity: <ce:italic>d<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>11.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, window: <ce:italic>d<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, void<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>51.7%)  are similar to those for MAF-4. Although the lone pair of uncoordinated nitrogen donor does not directly point into the pore, we have demonstrated that the pore surface of MAF-7 is obviously more active than that of MAF-4 . It should be noted that, the uncoordinated nitrogen donor is very close to the metal center (), which may directly attack, or help guest molecules to attack the metal centers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: MAF-7 is isomorphous with MAF-4. Their slightly different unit-cell parameters reflect size difference between the triazolate and imidazolate rings, or the nitrogen and carbon atoms. The ZnN4 geometry in MAF-7 (Zn-N 1.980(2)Å, N-Zn-N 108.62(15)-109.90(8)°) is slightly deviated from a regular tetrahedron. Although triazolates often behave as μ3-linkers in coordination compounds and Zn(II) can also adopt an octahedral coordination geometry, mtz- in MAF-7 uses only the 2- and 4-nitrogens for coordination, leaving the 1-nitrogen unbound. The waste of one coordination site should be ascribed to the steric hindrance of the hypothetical (3,6)-connected structure. Because mtz- does not contain a mirror symmetry along its C-C single bond, the 1-nitrogen in MAF-7 is symmetrically disordered with the 5-carbon (). The pore parameters of MAF-7 (cavity: d =11.2Å, window: d =3.4Å, void=51.7%)  are similar to those for MAF-4. Although the lone pair of uncoordinated nitrogen donor does not directly point into the pore, we have demonstrated that the pore surface of MAF-7 is obviously more active than that of MAF-4 . It should be noted that, the uncoordinated nitrogen donor is very close to the metal center (), which may directly attack, or help guest molecules to attack the metal centers.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0105" view="all">MAF-5 displays a regular ANA zeolitic network (<ce:italic>Ia</ce:italic>-3<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>) composed by Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, Zn<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, and Zn<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> rings. Compared with the SOD frameworks, the Zn atom in MAF-5 is coordinated in a distorted tetrahedral geometry (Zn–N 2.010(3)–2.020(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, N–Zn–N 103.9(2)–112.98(12)<ce:sup loc="post">°</ce:sup>), and also obviously not coplanar with the ligand ring (). The terminal methyl group of the ethyl group is statistically disordered over two positions. Interestingly, the occupancies of two positions (0.83/0.17) are obviously different with those observed in the as-synthesized phase measured at low temperature (0.50/0.50) , confirming the flexibility of the alkyl group. The pore system inside MAF-5 is interesting. An elongated, ellipsoidal cavity (<ce:italic>d<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>l<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) is enclosed by the <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> symmetric (6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) cage (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>a). Considering the disordered ethyl groups, the Zn<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> ring defines a very small, circular aperture with variable diameter (2.2–4.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), while the Zn<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> ring surrounds an irregular slit with fixed height (4.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and variable widths (5.8–9.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). When the 6-rings are regarded as impermeable, which would be true for large guest molecules and at low temperatures, each cavity is connected with three adjacent ones through the 8-rings to form a bicontinuous 3D pore system (racemic pair of <ce:bold>srs</ce:bold> nets, void<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>32.8% ) (b). Alternatively, the 2-fold interpenetrated <ce:bold>srs</ce:bold> nets are connected by the 6-rings to be a single 5-connected <ce:bold>gan</ce:bold> net () . By virtue of the pendant ethyl groups, the pore surface of MAF-5 should be very hydrophobic. It should be noted that the pore size of MAF-5 is similar to the technologically important, hydrophobic zeolite ZSM-5.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: MAF-5 displays a regular ANA zeolitic network (Ia-3d) composed by Zn4(eim)4, Zn6(eim)6, and Zn8(eim)8 rings. Compared with the SOD frameworks, the Zn atom in MAF-5 is coordinated in a distorted tetrahedral geometry (Zn-N 2.010(3)-2.020(3)Å, N-Zn-N 103.9(2)-112.98(12)°), and also obviously not coplanar with the ligand ring (). The terminal methyl group of the ethyl group is statistically disordered over two positions. Interestingly, the occupancies of two positions (0.83/0.17) are obviously different with those observed in the as-synthesized phase measured at low temperature (0.50/0.50) , confirming the flexibility of the alkyl group. The pore system inside MAF-5 is interesting. An elongated, ellipsoidal cavity (d =7.0Å, l =10.0Å) is enclosed by the D 3 symmetric (6283) cage ( a). Considering the disordered ethyl groups, the Zn6(eim)6 ring defines a very small, circular aperture with variable diameter (2.2-4.9Å), while the Zn8(eim)8 ring surrounds an irregular slit with fixed height (4.0Å) and variable widths (5.8-9.0Å). When the 6-rings are regarded as impermeable, which would be true for large guest molecules and at low temperatures, each cavity is connected with three adjacent ones through the 8-rings to form a bicontinuous 3D pore system (racemic pair of srs nets, void=32.8% ) (b). Alternatively, the 2-fold interpenetrated srs nets are connected by the 6-rings to be a single 5-connected gan net () . By virtue of the pendant ethyl groups, the pore surface of MAF-5 should be very hydrophobic. It should be noted that the pore size of MAF-5 is similar to the technologically important, hydrophobic zeolite ZSM-5.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0110" view="all">MAF-31 (<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> net)  and MAF-32 (<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>3<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>21, <ce:bold>qtz</ce:bold> net)  are nonporous supramolecular isomers of MAF-4 and MAF-5, respectively. In our study, single-crystal structure of MAF-32 can be only solved in the space groups of <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>3<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>21 rather than the reported one <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>6<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> from powder diffraction data . Compared with their porous isomers, the metal ions in MAF-31 and MAF-32 possess seriously distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, and deviate significantly from the coordination ligand rings (). MAF-33 (<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>4<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2, <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> net) is isoreticular to MAF-31, but less distorted due to the incorporation of bulkier ethyl groups (). It should be noted that the regular <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> topology has cubic symmetry (<ce:italic>Fd</ce:italic>-3<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>) . The etz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand in MAF-33 also coordinates in an imidazolate mode, but it uses the 1,4-nitrogens, being different to that in MAF-7 . The coordination geometries of metal ions and ligands in MAF-33 are similar to those in MAF-5 and much less distorted than for MAF-31 and MAF-32 ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: MAF-31 (P21/c, dia net)  and MAF-32 (P3221, qtz net)  are nonporous supramolecular isomers of MAF-4 and MAF-5, respectively. In our study, single-crystal structure of MAF-32 can be only solved in the space groups of P3221 rather than the reported one P64 from powder diffraction data . Compared with their porous isomers, the metal ions in MAF-31 and MAF-32 possess seriously distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, and deviate significantly from the coordination ligand rings (). MAF-33 (P43212, dia net) is isoreticular to MAF-31, but less distorted due to the incorporation of bulkier ethyl groups (). It should be noted that the regular dia topology has cubic symmetry (Fd-3m) . The etz- ligand in MAF-33 also coordinates in an imidazolate mode, but it uses the 1,4-nitrogens, being different to that in MAF-7 . The coordination geometries of metal ions and ligands in MAF-33 are similar to those in MAF-5 and much less distorted than for MAF-31 and MAF-32 ().

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0115" view="all">To study the structural diversity and optimize the bulk synthesis of zeolitic MAFs, pure or mixed low-boiling point solvents containing different concentration of CAA were used as the reaction solvents. The reactions were carried out using rapid solution mixing, heterogeneous mixing, liquid diffusion, and slow evaporation methods. As expected, single crystals of the desired MAFs can be only obtained by liquid diffusion or slow evaporation methods, while rapid solution mixing and heterogeneous mixing afforded microcrystalline samples.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

To study the structural diversity and optimize the bulk synthesis of zeolitic MAFs, pure or mixed low-boiling point solvents containing different concentration of CAA were used as the reaction solvents. The reactions were carried out using rapid solution mixing, heterogeneous mixing, liquid diffusion, and slow evaporation methods. As expected, single crystals of the desired MAFs can be only obtained by liquid diffusion or slow evaporation methods, while rapid solution mixing and heterogeneous mixing afforded microcrystalline samples.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0120" view="all">Many research groups showed that [Zn(mim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] trends to crystallize as the SOD structure MAF-4 in most reaction mechanisms and conditions . Only recently the <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> isomer of [Zn(mim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] was synthesized by Dong co-workers′ via hydrothermal reaction of Zn(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and excess Hmim . We found that room temperature reactions of Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Hmim in CAA produced pure MAF-31 (), while hydrothermal treatment of the reaction mixture yielded both MAF-31 and MAF-4 (). Hydrothermal treatment of Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Hmim at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in pure H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O affords single crystals of a nonporous polymer [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)(mim)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>] () mixed with microcrystalline MAF-4. Considering that nonporous structures should be more energetically stable, the preferential formation of the SOD isomer can be understood by comparison of the coordination geometries of the SOD and <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> isomers. Nevertheless, the presence of organic solvent such as methanol, ethanol, benzene, or toluene in the reaction solution is necessary for the synthesis of pure MAF-4.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Many research groups showed that [Zn(mim)2] trends to crystallize as the SOD structure MAF-4 in most reaction mechanisms and conditions . Only recently the dia isomer of [Zn(mim)2] was synthesized by Dong co-workers' via hydrothermal reaction of Zn(OAc)2 and excess Hmim . We found that room temperature reactions of Zn(OH)2 and Hmim in CAA produced pure MAF-31 (), while hydrothermal treatment of the reaction mixture yielded both MAF-31 and MAF-4 (). Hydrothermal treatment of Zn(OH)2 and Hmim at 120°C in pure H2O affords single crystals of a nonporous polymer [Zn3(OH)(mim)5] () mixed with microcrystalline MAF-4. Considering that nonporous structures should be more energetically stable, the preferential formation of the SOD isomer can be understood by comparison of the coordination geometries of the SOD and dia isomers. Nevertheless, the presence of organic solvent such as methanol, ethanol, benzene, or toluene in the reaction solution is necessary for the synthesis of pure MAF-4.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0125" view="all">Considering the importance of MAF-4, we selected MeOH as the main solvent, mixed with different concentrations of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O or CAA to optimize the bulk synthesis condition. Using pure methanol, Hmim reacts very slowly with solid Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> to form pure MAF-4. Even by general solvothermal treatment (ST) at 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h or microwave-assisted solvothermal (MW) treatment at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, a notable amount of Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> still exists, as being shown by PXRD (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>). Besides physical methods, the heterogeneous acid–base neutralization reaction can be facilitated by chemical means. In 4/1 mixed MeOH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, ST completes the reaction in 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, while MW requires 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (). In contrast, addition of CAA greatly accelerates the reaction, since NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> coordinates with Zn(II) and deprotonates Hmim. In 4/1 mixed MeOH/CAA, the reaction can be completed in 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at room temperature by stirring, or 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h by ST at 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, or 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h by MW at 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (). Without requirement of special apparatus, the room temperature heterogeneous mixing method can be easily scaled up. Hundreds of grams per batch have been attained using standard glass flask as the reaction container.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Considering the importance of MAF-4, we selected MeOH as the main solvent, mixed with different concentrations of H2O or CAA to optimize the bulk synthesis condition. Using pure methanol, Hmim reacts very slowly with solid Zn(OH)2 to form pure MAF-4. Even by general solvothermal treatment (ST) at 180°C for 24h or microwave-assisted solvothermal (MW) treatment at 160°C for 2h, a notable amount of Zn(OH)2 still exists, as being shown by PXRD ( ). Besides physical methods, the heterogeneous acid-base neutralization reaction can be facilitated by chemical means. In 4/1 mixed MeOH/H2O, ST completes the reaction in 30h at 180°C, while MW requires 3h at 120°C (). In contrast, addition of CAA greatly accelerates the reaction, since NH3 coordinates with Zn(II) and deprotonates Hmim. In 4/1 mixed MeOH/CAA, the reaction can be completed in 24h at room temperature by stirring, or 24h by ST at 40°C, or 2h by MW at 40°C (). Without requirement of special apparatus, the room temperature heterogeneous mixing method can be easily scaled up. Hundreds of grams per batch have been attained using standard glass flask as the reaction container.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0130" view="all">The yields of these heterogeneous mixing methods are nearly quantitative. Small amount of CAA (20%, <ce:italic>v</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>v</ce:italic>) does not lower the yield. More importantly, because the reactions produce MAF-4 and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O only, the remained mother liquor can be directly reused for another batch by further adding solid Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Hmim (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0075"></ce:float-anchor>). Such reaction cycles can be repeated for at least 5 times without lowering the purity or yield. Since heterogeneous mixing does not require complete dissolution of the starting materials, the reaction can be carried out in very high throughput, which is beneficial for industrial productions. Replacing Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> by ZnO only slightly reduces the reaction rate, offering another cheap and commercially available starting material.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The yields of these heterogeneous mixing methods are nearly quantitative. Small amount of CAA (20%, v/v) does not lower the yield. More importantly, because the reactions produce MAF-4 and H2O only, the remained mother liquor can be directly reused for another batch by further adding solid Zn(OH)2 and Hmim ( ). Such reaction cycles can be repeated for at least 5 times without lowering the purity or yield. Since heterogeneous mixing does not require complete dissolution of the starting materials, the reaction can be carried out in very high throughput, which is beneficial for industrial productions. Replacing Zn(OH)2 by ZnO only slightly reduces the reaction rate, offering another cheap and commercially available starting material.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0135" view="all">Rapid mixing of a CAA solution of Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and a methanol solution of Hmim at room temperature further shortens the overall preparation time to several hours, although employment of excess ammonia reduces the yield to about 70%. On the other hand, the mother liquor obtained in the rapid solution mixing method can be directly used as the reaction solvent for the heterogeneous mixing method.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Rapid mixing of a CAA solution of Zn(OH)2 and a methanol solution of Hmim at room temperature further shortens the overall preparation time to several hours, although employment of excess ammonia reduces the yield to about 70%. On the other hand, the mother liquor obtained in the rapid solution mixing method can be directly used as the reaction solvent for the heterogeneous mixing method.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0140" view="all">The [Zn(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] system can also crystallizes as a pair of porous/nonporous isomers in similar ways as [Zn(mim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]. Bulk synthesis of pure microcrystalline MAF-5 by rapid solution mixing or heterogeneous mixing requires the addition of a little aromatic solvent such as benzene (), otherwise pure microcrystalline MAF-32 would be obtained (). In contrast, aromatic solvent is not necessary for the single-crystal growth of MAF-5 by slow liquid diffusion , and single crystals of MAF-32 can be only obtained in the pure CAA solution without addition of any organic solvent. These observations indicate that the porous isomer MAF-5 can be easily obtained, but templating/structure directing agents are necessary especially for its fast crystallization.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The [Zn(eim)2] system can also crystallizes as a pair of porous/nonporous isomers in similar ways as [Zn(mim)2]. Bulk synthesis of pure microcrystalline MAF-5 by rapid solution mixing or heterogeneous mixing requires the addition of a little aromatic solvent such as benzene (), otherwise pure microcrystalline MAF-32 would be obtained (). In contrast, aromatic solvent is not necessary for the single-crystal growth of MAF-5 by slow liquid diffusion , and single crystals of MAF-32 can be only obtained in the pure CAA solution without addition of any organic solvent. These observations indicate that the porous isomer MAF-5 can be easily obtained, but templating/structure directing agents are necessary especially for its fast crystallization.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0145" view="all">In contrast to the syntheses of the imidazolates, the template or structure directing effect was not observed for the triazolates, and only MAF-7 and MAF-33 have been isolated so far (). Organic solvent is not necessary for the synthesis of MAF-7 and MAF-33. Because triazoles have much higher acidity than for imidazoles, the reaction requires lower concentrations of CAA.</ce:para>

Organic solvent is not necessary for the synthesis of MAF-7 and MAF-33. Because triazoles have much higher acidity than for imidazoles, the reaction requires lower concentrations of CAA.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Thermal and chemical stability</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0150" view="all">As shown by the TG curves (), all obtained MAFs are stable up to at least 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, except that MAF-7 decomposed just above 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. It should be noted that there is virtually no observable weight loss below the decomposition temperatures, indicating that the as-synthesized powder samples of porous MAFs can be easily activated by routine drying procedures, which is a remarkable improvement as compared to the common solvothermal methods using amides as solvents . Thermal stabilities of the porous MAFs were further checked by variable-temperature PXRD analyses, which revealed that MAF-7 collapsed above 170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (), being much lower than for MAF-4 and MAF-5 (>400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal and chemical stability

As shown by the TG curves (), all obtained MAFs are stable up to at least 400°C, except that MAF-7 decomposed just above 300°C. It should be noted that there is virtually no observable weight loss below the decomposition temperatures, indicating that the as-synthesized powder samples of porous MAFs can be easily activated by routine drying procedures, which is a remarkable improvement as compared to the common solvothermal methods using amides as solvents . Thermal stabilities of the porous MAFs were further checked by variable-temperature PXRD analyses, which revealed that MAF-7 collapsed above 170°C (), being much lower than for MAF-4 and MAF-5 (>400°C) .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0155" view="all">Chemical stabilities of the porous MAFs were checked by treatment of water, methanol, and benzene as typical solvents with different polarities. Guest-free microcrystalline samples were immersed in the solvent at a certain temperature for a period of time, after which their PXRD patterns were recorded and compared with the simulated ones. MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7 were stable in all tested solvents at room temperature and also in refluxing methanol and benzene for at least 7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days () . The chemical stabilities of these MAFs only degrade and show difference in boiling water. MAF-5 easily transforms to MAF-32 (), indicating that isomeric MAF-5 and MAF-32 are kinetically and thermodynamically favored phases in water, respectively. The transformation of MAF-4 to an unidentified phase can be detected after 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days () . For MAF-7, an unidentified phase also appears after 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days (). The low transformation/collapse rates at harsh conditions indicate that MAF-4 and MAF-7 are kinetically stable.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Chemical stabilities of the porous MAFs were checked by treatment of water, methanol, and benzene as typical solvents with different polarities. Guest-free microcrystalline samples were immersed in the solvent at a certain temperature for a period of time, after which their PXRD patterns were recorded and compared with the simulated ones. MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7 were stable in all tested solvents at room temperature and also in refluxing methanol and benzene for at least 7days () . The chemical stabilities of these MAFs only degrade and show difference in boiling water. MAF-5 easily transforms to MAF-32 (), indicating that isomeric MAF-5 and MAF-32 are kinetically and thermodynamically favored phases in water, respectively. The transformation of MAF-4 to an unidentified phase can be detected after 6days () . For MAF-7, an unidentified phase also appears after 2days (). The low transformation/collapse rates at harsh conditions indicate that MAF-4 and MAF-7 are kinetically stable.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0160" view="all">For comparison, MAF-4 and MAF-7 samples synthesized by other reagents/methods were subjected to the boiling water tests. The aqueous ammonia-assisted rapid solution mixing reaction can also use Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> as the metal ion source , but the obtained microcrystalline MAF-4 (ca. 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days) and MAF-7 (ca. 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>day) are less stable than those synthesized from Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (). Single crystals of MAF-4 obtained by solvothermal reaction of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Hmim in DMF kept intact for 9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days , but the manually grinded powder was damaged in less than 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>day (). These observations confirm that increasing crystal size can virtually improve the chemical stability. The fact that MAF samples synthesized from Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> have higher chemical stability should be attributed to trace impurity such as hydroxide and nitrate attached on the crystal surfaces and/or defects . Compared with other anions with larger size and lower basicity, hydroxide should bond stronger with metal ions, which prevents the crystal surface (hydroxide attached) from attacking/damaging by water molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For comparison, MAF-4 and MAF-7 samples synthesized by other reagents/methods were subjected to the boiling water tests. The aqueous ammonia-assisted rapid solution mixing reaction can also use Zn(NO3)2 as the metal ion source , but the obtained microcrystalline MAF-4 (ca. 3days) and MAF-7 (ca. 1day) are less stable than those synthesized from Zn(OH)2 (). Single crystals of MAF-4 obtained by solvothermal reaction of Zn(NO3)2 and Hmim in DMF kept intact for 9days , but the manually grinded powder was damaged in less than 1day (). These observations confirm that increasing crystal size can virtually improve the chemical stability. The fact that MAF samples synthesized from Zn(OH)2 have higher chemical stability should be attributed to trace impurity such as hydroxide and nitrate attached on the crystal surfaces and/or defects . Compared with other anions with larger size and lower basicity, hydroxide should bond stronger with metal ions, which prevents the crystal surface (hydroxide attached) from attacking/damaging by water molecules.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0165" view="all">The high thermal and chemical stabilities of MAFs are closely related to their unique structures such as strong coordination bonds and hydrophobic pore surfaces. The relatively low stability of MAF-7 should be attributed to the unbound nitrogen atoms close to the unsaturated Zn centers (Zn···N 2.96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The high thermal and chemical stabilities of MAFs are closely related to their unique structures such as strong coordination bonds and hydrophobic pore surfaces. The relatively low stability of MAF-7 should be attributed to the unbound nitrogen atoms close to the unsaturated Zn centers (Zn⋅⋅⋅N 2.96Å).

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Sorption property</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0170" view="all">Gas sorption isotherms (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 273 and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) were measured for the porous MAFs. The gas sorption data of the SOD frameworks are basically identical to our previous reports measured on the samples synthesized from soluble Zn(II) salts . According to their crystal structures, MAF-4 and MAF-7 show very similar and high porosity, while MAF-7 possesses much higher adsorption affinity for gas molecules. The porosity of ANA framework MAF-5 is lower than the SOD frameworks (), but still larger than most zeolites such as ZSM-5. The gas sorption affinity of MAF-5 is in between MAF-4 and MAF-7 (), because MAF-5 has smaller channel size and contains no pore surface active site.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Sorption property

Gas sorption isotherms (H2 and N2 at 77K, CO2 at 273 and 298K) were measured for the porous MAFs. The gas sorption data of the SOD frameworks are basically identical to our previous reports measured on the samples synthesized from soluble Zn(II) salts . According to their crystal structures, MAF-4 and MAF-7 show very similar and high porosity, while MAF-7 possesses much higher adsorption affinity for gas molecules. The porosity of ANA framework MAF-5 is lower than the SOD frameworks (), but still larger than most zeolites such as ZSM-5. The gas sorption affinity of MAF-5 is in between MAF-4 and MAF-7 (), because MAF-5 has smaller channel size and contains no pore surface active site.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0175" view="all">Water, methanol, and benzene sorption isotherms were also measured at room temperature. Virtually no water adsorption can be observed for the MAF-4 and MAF-5, demonstrating they are very rare hydrophobic adsorbents with high porosity. In contrast, MAF-7 have been shown moderate hydrophilicity and interesting water sorption behavior () . The MeOH sorption behaviors of these porous MAFs are very different from those for H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. As illustrated in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>, all the three materials can adsorb large amounts of MeOH corresponding to their pore volumes. All the sorption isotherms can be described as being type-IV, with abrupt increases of uptakes started at <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.13, 0.12, and 0.015 for MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7, respectively. The type-IV isotherms indicate that the host–guest interactions are weaker than the guest–guest ones. In other words, at low relative pressures, the adsorbents form weak interactions with the hydroxyl group and methyl groups of MeOH. Capillary condensation above the onset pressures are ascribed to hydrogen-bonding interactions among the adsorbed MeOH molecules. The lowest onset pressure of MAF-7 should be ascribed to the presence of uncoordinated nitrogen donors on its pore surface.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Water, methanol, and benzene sorption isotherms were also measured at room temperature. Virtually no water adsorption can be observed for the MAF-4 and MAF-5, demonstrating they are very rare hydrophobic adsorbents with high porosity. In contrast, MAF-7 have been shown moderate hydrophilicity and interesting water sorption behavior () . The MeOH sorption behaviors of these porous MAFs are very different from those for H2O. As illustrated in  , all the three materials can adsorb large amounts of MeOH corresponding to their pore volumes. All the sorption isotherms can be described as being type-IV, with abrupt increases of uptakes started at P/P 0 =0.13, 0.12, and 0.015 for MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7, respectively. The type-IV isotherms indicate that the host-guest interactions are weaker than the guest-guest ones. In other words, at low relative pressures, the adsorbents form weak interactions with the hydroxyl group and methyl groups of MeOH. Capillary condensation above the onset pressures are ascribed to hydrogen-bonding interactions among the adsorbed MeOH molecules. The lowest onset pressure of MAF-7 should be ascribed to the presence of uncoordinated nitrogen donors on its pore surface.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0180" view="all">Despite that the static window sizes are much smaller than the size of benzene (3.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>), the SOD MAFs can readily adsorb large amounts of benzene (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0060"></ce:float-anchor>). Similar to the case of MeOH, the onset pressure of benzene for MAF-7 is also lower than for MAF-4. Interestingly, MAF-5 starts to adsorb benzene at very low pressure (not detected), which should be due to the strong host–guest interaction (hydrophobic pore surface for hydrophobic guest) and the suitable pore sizes (slightly larger than that of benzene). The good hydrophilic/hydrophobic selectivities of MAF-4 and MAF-5 are useful for organic solvent/water separation. Especially, MAF-5 may be used for the removal/recycle of trace benzene in water.</ce:para>

Similar to the case of MeOH, the onset pressure of benzene for MAF-7 is also lower than for MAF-4. Interestingly, MAF-5 starts to adsorb benzene at very low pressure (not detected), which should be due to the strong host-guest interaction (hydrophobic pore surface for hydrophobic guest) and the suitable pore sizes (slightly larger than that of benzene). The good hydrophilic/hydrophobic selectivities of MAF-4 and MAF-5 are useful for organic solvent/water separation. Especially, MAF-5 may be used for the removal/recycle of trace benzene in water.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0185" view="all">The adsorption of larger molecules for MAF-4, -5, and -7 were semi-quantitatively monitored by TG analyses (). The activated samples of MAF-4, -5 and -7 were exposed in the saturated vapors of toluene (3.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) and <ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-xylene (3.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) for 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days before TG measurements. Adsorption on the outer surface is excluded by the observed significant weight losses. The large adsorption of organic molecules for MAF-5 demonstrates its ability as a hydrophobic adsorbate with high organic/water selectivity. As the molecular sizes of toluene and <ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-xylene are significantly larger than the aperture sizes of the SOD MAFs, structural transformation must occur . PXRD patterns of the solvent-loaded frameworks are reminiscent with the original host frameworks (), implying that the transformations occur during non-equilibrium states, i.e. the small windows only open temporarily to allow guest diffusion .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The adsorption of larger molecules for MAF-4, -5, and -7 were semi-quantitatively monitored by TG analyses (). The activated samples of MAF-4, -5 and -7 were exposed in the saturated vapors of toluene (3.3×7.3×7.3Å3) and p-xylene (3.8×6.3×9.1Å3) for 4days before TG measurements. Adsorption on the outer surface is excluded by the observed significant weight losses. The large adsorption of organic molecules for MAF-5 demonstrates its ability as a hydrophobic adsorbate with high organic/water selectivity. As the molecular sizes of toluene and p-xylene are significantly larger than the aperture sizes of the SOD MAFs, structural transformation must occur . PXRD patterns of the solvent-loaded frameworks are reminiscent with the original host frameworks (), implying that the transformations occur during non-equilibrium states, i.e. the small windows only open temporarily to allow guest diffusion .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0190" view="all">Monitoring the transient structure change during guest diffusion processes is difficult since X-ray diffraction data gives mostly the average structure parameters corresponding to the equilibrium states. Nevertheless, we carried out a preliminary in situ time-resolved PXRD analysis for MAF-4 during benzene adsorption. Powder sample of MAF-4 is exposed to a saturated vapor of benzene, and PXRD patterns were continuously scanned in a frequency of ca. 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min/run. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0065"></ce:float-anchor>, the PXRD pattern is unchanged at the beginning, but some of the peaks become broader after 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min, indicating local framework distortions during benzene diffusion. In other words, only some of the apertures in the whole host framework are temporarily distorted to allow passing of oversized guest, which degrade the periodicity of the crystal. After 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, the broadened peaks sharpen back to the starting state, but relative intensities of some peaks are different from the starting state, illustrating that the host framework is restored with perfect periodicity and benzene is included in the cavities.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Monitoring the transient structure change during guest diffusion processes is difficult since X-ray diffraction data gives mostly the average structure parameters corresponding to the equilibrium states. Nevertheless, we carried out a preliminary in situ time-resolved PXRD analysis for MAF-4 during benzene adsorption. Powder sample of MAF-4 is exposed to a saturated vapor of benzene, and PXRD patterns were continuously scanned in a frequency of ca. 2min/run. As shown in  , the PXRD pattern is unchanged at the beginning, but some of the peaks become broader after 10min, indicating local framework distortions during benzene diffusion. In other words, only some of the apertures in the whole host framework are temporarily distorted to allow passing of oversized guest, which degrade the periodicity of the crystal. After 1h, the broadened peaks sharpen back to the starting state, but relative intensities of some peaks are different from the starting state, illustrating that the host framework is restored with perfect periodicity and benzene is included in the cavities.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0195" view="all">A series of isostructural/isomeric Zn(II) monoalkyl substituted azolate frameworks have been synthesized. Detailed analyses of the single-crystal structures provided a deeper insight into the strong structure-directing role of substituent side groups and stability of the isomeric frameworks. The simple acid–base neutralization reaction between azole and ZnO/Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> can produce the required MAF material with water as the only byproduct. The reaction can be effectively activated by using aqueous ammonia as a recyclable coordination buffering agent, especially with the heterogeneous mixing approach.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of isostructural/isomeric Zn(II) monoalkyl substituted azolate frameworks have been synthesized. Detailed analyses of the single-crystal structures provided a deeper insight into the strong structure-directing role of substituent side groups and stability of the isomeric frameworks. The simple acid-base neutralization reaction between azole and ZnO/Zn(OH)2 can produce the required MAF material with water as the only byproduct. The reaction can be effectively activated by using aqueous ammonia as a recyclable coordination buffering agent, especially with the heterogeneous mixing approach.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0200" view="all">The obtained porous MAFs show higher chemical stability compared with other preparation methods, which is tentatively assigned to the impact of different impurity. Sample activation is also easier because no high-boiling point solvent is employed. Sorption behaviors of the porous MAFs can be explained by their pore size and surface properties. Due to the complete coordination of nitrogen donors and alkyl-lined pore surface, the imidazolate frameworks MAF-4 and MAF-5 are rare hydrophobic adsorbents with high pore volumes, which can easily adsorb large amount of organic solvent but do not adsorb water even at very high humidity. As the pore size is similar to small aromatic derivatives such as benzene and toluene, MAF-5 is suitable for removal of trace aromatic molecules from water. On the other hand, the large pore MAF-4 exhibits lower adsorption affinity for organic solvents, and significant adsorption arise from capillary condensation. While MAF-7 is isostructural with MAF-4, incorporation of uncoordinated nitrogen donor on the pore surface increases the sorption affinity and lowers the onset pressure of capillary condensation. Finally, the SOD frameworks MAF-4 and MAF-7 can readily adsorb guest molecules obviously larger than their aperture sizes via temporary distortion of their frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The obtained porous MAFs show higher chemical stability compared with other preparation methods, which is tentatively assigned to the impact of different impurity. Sample activation is also easier because no high-boiling point solvent is employed. Sorption behaviors of the porous MAFs can be explained by their pore size and surface properties. Due to the complete coordination of nitrogen donors and alkyl-lined pore surface, the imidazolate frameworks MAF-4 and MAF-5 are rare hydrophobic adsorbents with high pore volumes, which can easily adsorb large amount of organic solvent but do not adsorb water even at very high humidity. As the pore size is similar to small aromatic derivatives such as benzene and toluene, MAF-5 is suitable for removal of trace aromatic molecules from water. On the other hand, the large pore MAF-4 exhibits lower adsorption affinity for organic solvents, and significant adsorption arise from capillary condensation. While MAF-7 is isostructural with MAF-4, incorporation of uncoordinated nitrogen donor on the pore surface increases the sorption affinity and lowers the onset pressure of capillary condensation. Finally, the SOD frameworks MAF-4 and MAF-7 can readily adsorb guest molecules obviously larger than their aperture sizes via temporary distortion of their frameworks.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">All MAF samples were synthesized in the acid–base neutralization reaction mechanism started with the corresponding azole ligand (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and ZnO or Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol). Several methods are employed to accomplish the reactions:<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="o0005">
<ce:label>(1)</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0215" view="all">Rapid solution mixing: ZnO/Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was dissolved in a minimum amount of CAA, to which a solution of an azole ligand is added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, and then filtered, washed by methanol, and dried at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in air to give white powder as the product.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="o0010">
<ce:label>(2)</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0220" view="all">Heterogeneous mixing: ZnO/Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, an azole ligand, and a ‘reaction solvent’ were mixed and stirred at room temperature or (microwave) heated in a sealed vessel. Workup procedure followed method 1. The ‘reaction solvent’ can be pure water, methanol, CAA, mixture of these reagents, or mother liquor obtained from method 1 and 2.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="o0015">
<ce:label>(3)</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0225" view="all">Slow solution mixing (liquid diffusion): A methanol solution of an azole ligand (0.050<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L) was carefully layered on the CAA solution of ZnO/Zn(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (0.025<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L). Single crystals were obtained after several days.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

All MAF samples were synthesized in the acid-base neutralization reaction mechanism started with the corresponding azole ligand (2mmol) and ZnO or Zn(OH)2 (1mmol). Several methods are employed to accomplish the reactions:  (1) Rapid solution mixing: ZnO/Zn(OH)2 was dissolved in a minimum amount of CAA, to which a solution of an azole ligand is added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 5h, and then filtered, washed by methanol, and dried at 120°C in air to give white powder as the product.   (2) Heterogeneous mixing: ZnO/Zn(OH)2, an azole ligand, and a ‘reaction solvent' were mixed and stirred at room temperature or (microwave) heated in a sealed vessel. Workup procedure followed method 1. The ‘reaction solvent' can be pure water, methanol, CAA, mixture of these reagents, or mother liquor obtained from method 1 and 2.   (3) Slow solution mixing (liquid diffusion): A methanol solution of an azole ligand (0.050mol/L) was carefully layered on the CAA solution of ZnO/Zn(OH)2 (0.025mol/L). Single crystals were obtained after several days.   (4) Slow evaporation: ZnO/Zn(OH)2 and an azole ligand were added with an excess amount of CAA, and then the mixture was filtered to get a clear solution, which was allowed to evaporate slowly. Single crystals were obtained after several days.   

Slow solution mixing (liquid diffusion): A methanol solution of an azole ligand (0.050mol/L) was carefully layered on the CAA solution of ZnO/Zn(OH)2 (0.025mol/L). Single crystals were obtained after several days.

Typical synthetic procedures for the studied MAFs

SOD-[Zn(mim)2] (MAF-4): Single crystals were obtained by method 3 . Powder samples were obtained by method 1 (yield: 75%) or 2 (yield:>95%). In method 1, a methanol solution of Hmim (0.1mol/L) was used. In method 2, when the ‘reaction solution' is methanol added with CAA (20%, v/v), the reaction time is 24h for room temperature stirring, or 24h for 40°C solvothermal treatment, or 1.5h for 40°C microwave-assisted solvotherml treatment; when the ‘reaction solution' is methanol added with water (20%, v/v), the reaction time is 24h for 180°C solvothermal treatment, or 2.5h for 120°C microwave-assisted solvothermal treatment.

SOD-[Zn(mtz)2] (MAF-7): Single crystals were obtained by method 4. Powder samples were obtained by method 1 using a water solution of Hmtz (yield: 70%), or by method 2 using a reaction solvent of water added with 5% CAA.   dia-[Zn(mim)2] (MAF-31): Single crystals were obtained by method 4 (yield: 70%).    qtz-[Zn(eim)2] (MAF-32): Single crystals were obtained by method 4 (yield: 93%).    dia-[Zn(etz)2] (MAF-33): Single crystals were obtained by method 4 (yield: 63%).   

 dia-[Zn(mim)2] (MAF-31): Single crystals were obtained by method 4 (yield: 70%).

 qtz-[Zn(eim)2] (MAF-32): Single crystals were obtained by method 4 (yield: 93%).

 dia-[Zn(etz)2] (MAF-33): Single crystals were obtained by method 4 (yield: 63%).

X-ray crystallography

Diffraction intensities were collected on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation, equipped with an open dry nitrogen flow temperature controller. Absorption corrections were applied by using multi-scan program SADABS . The structures were solved with direct methods and refined with a full-matrix least-squares technique with the SHELXTL program package . Anisotropic thermal parameters were applied to all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically and refined in a riding mode ( ).

Considering the importance of MAF-4, we selected MeOH as the main solvent, mixed with different concentrations of H2O or CAA to optimize the bulk synthesis condition. Using pure methanol, Hmim reacts very slowly with solid Zn(OH)2 to form pure MAF-4. Even by general solvothermal treatment (ST) at 180°C for 24h or microwave-assisted solvothermal (MW) treatment at 160°C for 2h, a notable amount of Zn(OH)2 still exists, as being shown by PXRD ( ). Besides physical methods, the heterogeneous acid-base neutralization reaction can be facilitated by chemical means. In 4/1 mixed MeOH/H2O, ST completes the reaction in 30h at 180°C, while MW requires 3h at 120°C (). In contrast, addition of CAA greatly accelerates the reaction, since NH3 coordinates with Zn(II) and deprotonates Hmim. In 4/1 mixed MeOH/CAA, the reaction can be completed in 24h at room temperature by stirring, or 24h by ST at 40°C, or 2h by MW at 40°C (). Without requirement of special apparatus, the room temperature heterogeneous mixing method can be easily scaled up. Hundreds of grams per batch have been attained using standard glass flask as the reaction container.
