<ce:para id="p0100" view="all">MAF-7 is isomorphous with MAF-4. Their slightly different unit-cell parameters reflect size difference between the triazolate and imidazolate rings, or the nitrogen and carbon atoms. The ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> geometry in MAF-7 (Zn–N 1.980(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, N–Zn–N 108.62(15)–109.90(8)°) is slightly deviated from a regular tetrahedron. Although triazolates often behave as μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-linkers in coordination compounds and Zn(II) can also adopt an octahedral coordination geometry, mtz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> in MAF-7 uses only the 2- and 4-nitrogens for coordination, leaving the 1-nitrogen unbound. The waste of one coordination site should be ascribed to the steric hindrance of the hypothetical (3,6)-connected structure. Because mtz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> does not contain a mirror symmetry along its C–C single bond, the 1-nitrogen in MAF-7 is symmetrically disordered with the 5-carbon (). The pore parameters of MAF-7 (cavity: <ce:italic>d<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>11.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, window: <ce:italic>d<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, void<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>51.7%)  are similar to those for MAF-4. Although the lone pair of uncoordinated nitrogen donor does not directly point into the pore, we have demonstrated that the pore surface of MAF-7 is obviously more active than that of MAF-4 . It should be noted that, the uncoordinated nitrogen donor is very close to the metal center (), which may directly attack, or help guest molecules to attack the metal centers.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">MAF-5 displays a regular ANA zeolitic network (<ce:italic>Ia</ce:italic>-3<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>) composed by Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, Zn<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, and Zn<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> rings. Compared with the SOD frameworks, the Zn atom in MAF-5 is coordinated in a distorted tetrahedral geometry (Zn–N 2.010(3)–2.020(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, N–Zn–N 103.9(2)–112.98(12)<ce:sup loc="post">°</ce:sup>), and also obviously not coplanar with the ligand ring (). The terminal methyl group of the ethyl group is statistically disordered over two positions. Interestingly, the occupancies of two positions (0.83/0.17) are obviously different with those observed in the as-synthesized phase measured at low temperature (0.50/0.50) , confirming the flexibility of the alkyl group. The pore system inside MAF-5 is interesting. An elongated, ellipsoidal cavity (<ce:italic>d<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>l<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) is enclosed by the <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> symmetric (6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) cage (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>a). Considering the disordered ethyl groups, the Zn<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> ring defines a very small, circular aperture with variable diameter (2.2–4.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), while the Zn<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> ring surrounds an irregular slit with fixed height (4.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and variable widths (5.8–9.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). When the 6-rings are regarded as impermeable, which would be true for large guest molecules and at low temperatures, each cavity is connected with three adjacent ones through the 8-rings to form a bicontinuous 3D pore system (racemic pair of <ce:bold>srs</ce:bold> nets, void<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>32.8% ) (b). Alternatively, the 2-fold interpenetrated <ce:bold>srs</ce:bold> nets are connected by the 6-rings to be a single 5-connected <ce:bold>gan</ce:bold> net () . By virtue of the pendant ethyl groups, the pore surface of MAF-5 should be very hydrophobic. It should be noted that the pore size of MAF-5 is similar to the technologically important, hydrophobic zeolite ZSM-5.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Thermal and chemical stability</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0150" view="all">As shown by the TG curves (), all obtained MAFs are stable up to at least 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, except that MAF-7 decomposed just above 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. It should be noted that there is virtually no observable weight loss below the decomposition temperatures, indicating that the as-synthesized powder samples of porous MAFs can be easily activated by routine drying procedures, which is a remarkable improvement as compared to the common solvothermal methods using amides as solvents . Thermal stabilities of the porous MAFs were further checked by variable-temperature PXRD analyses, which revealed that MAF-7 collapsed above 170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (), being much lower than for MAF-4 and MAF-5 (>400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) .</ce:para><ce:para id="p0175" view="all">Water, methanol, and benzene sorption isotherms were also measured at room temperature. Virtually no water adsorption can be observed for the MAF-4 and MAF-5, demonstrating they are very rare hydrophobic adsorbents with high porosity. In contrast, MAF-7 have been shown moderate hydrophilicity and interesting water sorption behavior () . The MeOH sorption behaviors of these porous MAFs are very different from those for H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. As illustrated in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>, all the three materials can adsorb large amounts of MeOH corresponding to their pore volumes. All the sorption isotherms can be described as being type-IV, with abrupt increases of uptakes started at <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.13, 0.12, and 0.015 for MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7, respectively. The type-IV isotherms indicate that the host–guest interactions are weaker than the guest–guest ones. In other words, at low relative pressures, the adsorbents form weak interactions with the hydroxyl group and methyl groups of MeOH. Capillary condensation above the onset pressures are ascribed to hydrogen-bonding interactions among the adsorbed MeOH molecules. The lowest onset pressure of MAF-7 should be ascribed to the presence of uncoordinated nitrogen donors on its pore surface.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
MAF-7 is isomorphous with MAF-4. Their slightly different unit-cell parameters reflect size difference between the triazolate and imidazolate rings, or the nitrogen and carbon atoms. The ZnN4 geometry in MAF-7 (Zn-N 1.980(2)Å, N-Zn-N 108.62(15)-109.90(8)°) is slightly deviated from a regular tetrahedron. Although triazolates often behave as μ3-linkers in coordination compounds and Zn(II) can also adopt an octahedral coordination geometry, mtz- in MAF-7 uses only the 2- and 4-nitrogens for coordination, leaving the 1-nitrogen unbound. The waste of one coordination site should be ascribed to the steric hindrance of the hypothetical (3,6)-connected structure. Because mtz- does not contain a mirror symmetry along its C-C single bond, the 1-nitrogen in MAF-7 is symmetrically disordered with the 5-carbon (). The pore parameters of MAF-7 (cavity: d =11.2Å, window: d =3.4Å, void=51.7%)  are similar to those for MAF-4. Although the lone pair of uncoordinated nitrogen donor does not directly point into the pore, we have demonstrated that the pore surface of MAF-7 is obviously more active than that of MAF-4 . It should be noted that, the uncoordinated nitrogen donor is very close to the metal center (), which may directly attack, or help guest molecules to attack the metal centers.

MAF-5 displays a regular ANA zeolitic network (Ia-3d) composed by Zn4(eim)4, Zn6(eim)6, and Zn8(eim)8 rings. Compared with the SOD frameworks, the Zn atom in MAF-5 is coordinated in a distorted tetrahedral geometry (Zn-N 2.010(3)-2.020(3)Å, N-Zn-N 103.9(2)-112.98(12)°), and also obviously not coplanar with the ligand ring (). The terminal methyl group of the ethyl group is statistically disordered over two positions. Interestingly, the occupancies of two positions (0.83/0.17) are obviously different with those observed in the as-synthesized phase measured at low temperature (0.50/0.50) , confirming the flexibility of the alkyl group. The pore system inside MAF-5 is interesting. An elongated, ellipsoidal cavity (d =7.0Å, l =10.0Å) is enclosed by the D 3 symmetric (6283) cage ( a). Considering the disordered ethyl groups, the Zn6(eim)6 ring defines a very small, circular aperture with variable diameter (2.2-4.9Å), while the Zn8(eim)8 ring surrounds an irregular slit with fixed height (4.0Å) and variable widths (5.8-9.0Å). When the 6-rings are regarded as impermeable, which would be true for large guest molecules and at low temperatures, each cavity is connected with three adjacent ones through the 8-rings to form a bicontinuous 3D pore system (racemic pair of srs nets, void=32.8% ) (b). Alternatively, the 2-fold interpenetrated srs nets are connected by the 6-rings to be a single 5-connected gan net () . By virtue of the pendant ethyl groups, the pore surface of MAF-5 should be very hydrophobic. It should be noted that the pore size of MAF-5 is similar to the technologically important, hydrophobic zeolite ZSM-5.

Thermal and chemical stability

As shown by the TG curves (), all obtained MAFs are stable up to at least 400°C, except that MAF-7 decomposed just above 300°C. It should be noted that there is virtually no observable weight loss below the decomposition temperatures, indicating that the as-synthesized powder samples of porous MAFs can be easily activated by routine drying procedures, which is a remarkable improvement as compared to the common solvothermal methods using amides as solvents . Thermal stabilities of the porous MAFs were further checked by variable-temperature PXRD analyses, which revealed that MAF-7 collapsed above 170°C (), being much lower than for MAF-4 and MAF-5 (>400°C) .

Water, methanol, and benzene sorption isotherms were also measured at room temperature. Virtually no water adsorption can be observed for the MAF-4 and MAF-5, demonstrating they are very rare hydrophobic adsorbents with high porosity. In contrast, MAF-7 have been shown moderate hydrophilicity and interesting water sorption behavior () . The MeOH sorption behaviors of these porous MAFs are very different from those for H2O. As illustrated in  , all the three materials can adsorb large amounts of MeOH corresponding to their pore volumes. All the sorption isotherms can be described as being type-IV, with abrupt increases of uptakes started at P/P 0 =0.13, 0.12, and 0.015 for MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7, respectively. The type-IV isotherms indicate that the host-guest interactions are weaker than the guest-guest ones. In other words, at low relative pressures, the adsorbents form weak interactions with the hydroxyl group and methyl groups of MeOH. Capillary condensation above the onset pressures are ascribed to hydrogen-bonding interactions among the adsorbed MeOH molecules. The lowest onset pressure of MAF-7 should be ascribed to the presence of uncoordinated nitrogen donors on its pore surface.
